#Text=Ryanair sue
#Text=Associated Newspapers , Mirror Group
#Text=Saturday , August 17 , 2013

#Text=Irish budget airline Ryanair have added newspaper publishers Associated Newspapers and Mirror Group to their legal targets in a High Court defamation action filed yesterday in Dublin that also targets Channel 4 .
#Text=A Ryanair Boeing 737 pictured in 2006 .
#Text=Image : WikiABG .
#Text=The move confirms the carrier 's expression of intent to sue Channel 4 after the UK broadcaster screened Secrets of the Cockpit , a documentary about safety at the airline , on Monday night .
#Text=Part of the Dispatches series , the show reported on an incident in Spain last year where three Ryanair jets declared fuel emergencies after being diverted to Valencia .
#Text=Fuel policy was a strong focus for the documentary .
#Text=Pilots interviewed for the programme said they felt pressured to save fuel , the cost of which has hit Ryanair 's profits .
#Text=The Spanish Air Authority described Ryanair flights usually landing with a bare minimum of fuel , in a report the airline dismissed as " manifestly inaccurate and factually untrue " .
#Text=Ryanair have also sacked veteran pilot John Goss for appearing on the show , the only pilot interviewed who did not seek anonymity .
#Text=Ryanair have stated intent to sue Goss and claim he confirmed in the weeks before the show that he had no issues with his employer 's safety .
#Text=Goss is a member of Ryanair Pilots Group ( RPG ) , which the airline call a union front .
#Text=Channel 4 previously promised when threatened with legal action to see Ryanair in court .
#Text=" We stand by our journalism , and will robustly defend proceedings if they are initiated , " a spokesperson said .
#Text=The Belfast Telegraph was also sued but the action has been dropped after the Northern Irish publication issued an apology .
#Text=The paper had published a story titled " Are budget airlines like Ryanair putting passengers at risk ? " .

column1: #Text=Associated Newspapers are behind The Daily Mail and its online and Sunday variants .
#Text=Mirror Group publish The Daily Mirror , its Sunday sister , and The People .
#Text=Secrets of the Cockpit also examined an RPG poll of 1,000 Ryanair flight crew , dismissed by the airline as part of unionisation efforts .
#Text=According to the RPG survey almost 90 % of respondents said the safety culture was nontransparent .
#Text=Two-thirds said they felt uncomfortable raising safety issues , with a pilot interviewed by Channel 4 accusing Ryanair of " threats and bullying " .
#Text=Ryanair had told pilots anybody signing a " so-called safety petition " might be dismissed .

column1: #Text=Over 90 % of those surveyed wanted a regulatory inquiry , with RPG saying the survey results were passed to the airline and the Irish Aviation Authority ( IAA ) .

#Text=The IAA has already called the programme a " misguided attack " on Ryanair , saying " Ryanair Plc fully complies with all European and international regulations in all areas of its operations " .
#Text=We have been instructed to vigorously prosecute these libel proceedings — Ryanair 's lawyers

#Text=The IAA itself was accused of failing to respond to concerns from Ryanair pilots and one interviewee said his " personal belief is that the majority of Ryanair pilots do not have confidence in the safety agencies and that is a pretty critical issue " .

#Text=The authority responded " The IAA has responded to personal letters and reports from Ryanair pilots , this included several meetings and face-to-face interviews with pilots and their legal and professional representatives . "

#Text=Ryanair makes heavy use of zero-hour contracts , which do not guarantee work and which the Irish Airline Pilots ' Association describe as offering some of aviation 's worst employment conditions .

#Text=RPG chairman Evert van Zwol , also a recent Dutch Airline Pilots Association president , said zero-hour contracts tended to make pilots choose to fly when unwell and keep quiet if they had safety concerns .
#Text=In 2005 a Polish Ryanair pilot became lost near Rome a few days after attending his son 's funeral , while his Dutch co-pilot was seeing his first experience of navigating severe weather .
#Text=In the 2005 incident air traffic control intervened to keep the flight safe from midair collisions .
#Text=The Polish pilot told Italian investigators he feared losing his job if he took extra time off work .
#Text=The investigation concluded in 2009 he had been unfit to fly .
#Text=Ryanair denied he would have been fired for taking time off to recover .

#Text=Secrets of the Cockpit also reported that in twelve separate serious incidents data from cockpit voice recorders had been wiped before investigators could access it , which the carrier says is a common occcurrence in aviation and attributed to pilot error .

#Text=In Sweden a report into a Ryanair emergency landing concluded this week an airline employee wiped the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder to prevent the investigation accessing them .
#Text=The aircraft had returned to an airport near Stockholm shortly after takeoff suffering electrical malfunctions .

#Text=Ryanair reject the Swedish Accident Investigation Authority 's take on the missing data , telling newspaper Södermanlands Nyheter recordings were reset by a technician trying to repair the aircraft after consultation with Ryanair 's technical department , who did not think the recordings needed saving .
#Text=Ryanair , which has never suffered a fatal accident , says the documentary is " false and defamatory " , and the IAA says it is " based upon false and misleading information " .
#Text=" We have been instructed to vigorously prosecute these libel proceedings , " said a statement from Ryanair 's lawyers , who promised " other litigation is pending " .
